comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: Possibly Albert S Janin, who had legal fights over several years with Curtiss over a seaplane patent Janin filed in 1911.

comment.author: 76126961@N06
comment._content: Cool could you be my friend on Flickr please

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: In January 26, 1915, the NYT reported that Janin had a prior claim to the design concept Curtiss used (although Janin never got enough money to actually build anything) query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F3061EFA3E5C13738... The skirmishing between Curtiss and Janin seems to have gone on for a decade or so. Janin's 1931 obituary [ select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F40C1FFF355C157A... access requires subscription] indicates that Curtiss won out eventually. Given a slightly unusual name and the fact that he was in the news in January 1915 makes me think I've probably found the right guy.

comment.author: 35014516@N03
comment._content: swanq:  You're right, it does seem probable this is the same Janin. We'll include some of your new information next time we update.
